Many chemical reactions and biological functions depend on the activation of dioxygen (O2). The development of effective and selective electrocatalysts for O2 activation, which is necessary for use in oxygen sensors, fuel cells, and other electrochemical devices, remains a difficulty despite the significance of this process. Due to their clearly defined structures, adaptable characteristics, and high catalytic activity, molecular models have recently become prominent contenders for electrocatalytic O2 activation. This review concentrates on the synthesis, modification, and performance evaluation of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for O2 activation. The benefits and drawbacks of several molecular model types, such as metalloporphyrins, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), and metalloenzymes as electrocatalysts for O2 activation, are examined in length. Due to their adjustable porosity, large surface area, and capacity to incorporate various metal ions, MOFs are a particularly interesting family of molecular models. Contrarily, metalloporphyrins are well known for their high preference and catalytic activity for O2 activation. The realization of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for O2 activation constitutes a viable path for the creation of efficient, durable, and selective electrochemical devices. Keywords Dioxygen activation Heterogeneous electrocatalysts Molecular models Catalytic activity Selectivity Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction 1.1 Energy demand/market scenario/fuel cells/metal-air batteries Energy demand is the quantity of energy needed to meet the demands of a specific industry, sector, or population. It is a key driver of energy markets around the world, and ensuring a dependable and sustainable energy supply for the future requires understanding the dynamics of energy demand and the market environment [1,2]. Many variables, such as population expansion, industrialization, technological development, and shifting consumer tastes, drive the demand for energy. Energy demand is significantly influenced by economic growth since more economic activities necessitate more energy for manufacturing, transportation, and other uses. As more people live in a given area, there is a corresponding increase in the amount of energy needed for heating, lighting, cooking, and other daily activities [3]. While industrial operations require considerable amounts of energy to power machinery and equipment, industrialization is another important factor driving the demand for energy. The proliferation of various electronic devices and the expansion of the internet are examples of technological developments that have increased energy usage. Consumer preferences that are changing, such as the shift towards electric vehicles and renewable energy sources, have an impact on energy demand and market dynamics. The production, distribution, and transportation of energy resources are all part of the intricate energy market system. Many factors, such as geopolitical developments, technological improvements, environmental restrictions, and demand and supply dynamics, have an impact on the energy market scenario [4]. A variety of energy sources, including fossil fuels like oil, coal, and natural gas, as well as renewable energy sources like solar, wind, and hydroelectric power, are used to meet global energy demand. Supply and demand, in a highly competitive market, influence energy pricing. A rising understanding of how energy production and usage affect the environment has resulted in increased efforts to switch to greener and more sustainable energy sources in recent years. The energy market has changed due to the advancement of renewable energy technology, which has caused a shift away from conventional fossil fuels and towards renewable energy sources [5,6]. For policy makers, energy producers, and energy consumers, it is essential to comprehend the dynamics of energy demand and the market environment. A sustainable and dependable energy supply for the future depends on remaining educated about the changes in the energy market, which is a dynamic system that is influenced by the above-mentioned different elements. Metal-air batteries (MABs) and fuel cells (FCs) are two different types of electrochemical devices that can produce electricity. Both are cleaner and more effective than conventional combustion engines because they turn chemical energy straight into electrical energy without burning. Fuel cells are devices that use hydrogen and oxygen to produce electricity. The oxygen is acquired from the air, while the hydrogen is often kept in a separate tank. The hydrogen is divided inside the fuel cell into electrons and protons, which move in distinct directions to the anode and cathode, respectively [7,8]. The only consequence of the process is water, which is formed at the cathode when oxygen interacts with protons and electrons. An electron flow produced by this technique can be converted into electrical energy [8]. Proton exchange membrane (PEM), alkaline, solid oxide, and phosphoric acid fuel cells are among the various types of fuel cells. PEM fuel cells are widely utilized in portable electronics and vehicles because of their great efficiency. Electrochemical cells known as MABs produce energy by reacting a metal (often aluminum or zinc) with oxygen from the surrounding atmosphere. The cathode is oxygen, while the anode is metal. The metal and oxygen combine to form metal oxide, which releases electrons that can be converted into electrical energy [9]. MABs are able to store a lot of energy in a small amount of space thanks to their high energy density. They also have a long shelf life and are lightweight. They are not appropriate for high-power applications because of their limitations, which include a relatively poor power density [10,11]. The generalized configuration of MABs as well as the chemical reactions based on electrolyte type and issues associated with the cathode and anode have been presented in Fig. 1 . Hearing aids, military weapons, and remote sensors frequently use metal-air batteries. 1.2 Expectation from molecular models for oxygen activation Molecular modeling is the process of predicting and analyzing the characteristics and behavior of molecules using computer programs and algorithms. In the domains of materials research, energy storage, drug development, and many others, it is a crucial instrument. There are various kinds of molecular modeling methods, such as quantum mechanical calculations, docking investigations, and simulations of molecular dynamics. The capacity to precisely predict a molecule's properties is one of the main goals of molecular modeling. This covers stability, solubility, and reactivity, which are crucial for creating materials that work. The capacity to imitate molecules' behavior under varied circumstances is a further expectation of molecular modeling. This entails modeling molecules' motion in solutions and their interactions with other molecules and surfaces [12,13]. For instance, molecular dynamics simulations are particularly helpful since they let scientists/researchers observe how molecules behave over time. The use of molecular modeling to create new materials with specific features has gained popularity in recent years. For instance, scientists have developed new sensors, catalysts, and electronic materials using molecular modeling. Although this field of study is still in its infancy, it has the potential to completely alter how we create new materials. Molecular modeling faces several difficulties, such as the necessity for precise force fields and the constraints of available processing capacity. Nonetheless, it is anticipated that improvements in hardware and software will overcome these issues and further boost the precision and effectiveness of molecular modeling. In the process of oxygen activation, the strong O-O bond of molecular oxygen (O2) is broken, and the activated oxygen species then reacts with a substrate. Combustion, photosynthesis, and respiration, are just a few of the significant chemical and biological reactions that depend on this process [13,14]. In many fields of chemistry, understanding the reaction mechanisms of oxygen activation is crucial, and computational modeling has become an effective tool for researching these procedures. The complexity of the associated chemical pathways represents one of the primary difficulties in investigating oxygen activation [15,16]. Several processes for oxygen activation have been put forth, depending on the system and reaction conditions being researched. Many reactive intermediates, such as radical species, metal-oxo species, and high-valent metal complexes, may be involved in these pathways [17]. As it enables researchers to investigate the intermediates and reaction pathways involved in the process in a quantitative and systematic manner, computational modeling has grown in importance as a technique for understanding oxygen activation. Oxygen activation has been investigated using a range of molecular modeling techniques, including molecular dynamics (MD) simulations [16], molecular mechanics/quantum mechanics (MM/QM) [18], and density functional theory (DFT) [19,20]. A system's dynamics and conformational changes can be explored using MD simulations, which can also shed light on the mechanisms underlying complicated chemical reactions. The reactivity and electronic structure of transition metal complexes, which are frequently implicated in oxygen activation, can be better understood through the use of DFT calculations. Researchers can represent the reactive region of a complex system using complicated QM/MM calculations while addressing the remainder of the system at a lower level. A variety of oxygen activation processes, including those involving radical intermediates and metal-oxo species, have been studied using this methodology. Electron transfer processes within complex systems during O2 activation can also be studied, as shown in Fig. 2 . 1.3 Heterogenous molecular electrocatalysts A group of materials known as heterogeneous molecular electrocatalysts are employed to catalyze chemical reactions using electrochemistry. Typically, these materials are made of metal complexes that are bonded to a support substance like silica, carbon, or metal oxide. The content and structure of the metal complexes might vary, but they are typically made to facilitate the desired chemical reaction with a high degree of efficiency and selectivity. The versatility of heterogeneous molecular electrocatalysts is one of their main benefits [22–24]. They can be made to catalyze a variety of processes, including the oxidation of water [25,26], the reduction of carbon dioxide [27,28], and organic molecules hydrogenation [29]. They are very desirable for a wide range of applications, including chemical synthesis, energy conversion and storage, and environmental remediation, due to their versatility. Immobilizing molecular catalysts on conductive material supports (a non-homogeneous phase of the molecular catalysts) has several advantages, including (i) the promise of exposing a high density of active sites due to the catalyst's direct local bonding with the electrode surface. This shortens the path that electrons must travel to get from the electrode to the catalyst site for O2 activation; (ii) additionally, the solid support is generally chosen for its outstanding conductivity, which ensures the effective e- transfer during the catalysis; (iii) using heterogeneous systems permits molecular catalysts to circumvent their solubility constraints, allowing them to function in proton-rich environmentally friendly aqueous solutions. In addition, molecular catalysts have different frontier energy levels that can be adjusted by modifying their molecular core through substitution, axial ligation, change in substituent's position, and change in secondary coordination-sphere. Their O2 binding ability and redox potential, both of which are crucial during O2 activation, are closely related to their energy levels. Based on these observations, multiphase O2 activation can be regulated by keeping tabs on the energy difference between the molecular catalysts' eg-orbital and the π* orbital of O2. Therefore, an effective multiphase dioxygen activation electrocatalyst can be obtained via carefully regulated molecular preparation. Heterogeneous molecule electrocatalysts need to have several essential qualities in order to serve as effective electrocatalysts. First, the ability to adsorb reactant molecules onto their surfaces, which calls for a large surface area and suitable chemical functional groups, is a major requirement. They must also have a suitable redox potential and good electrical conductivity to allow the transport of electrons between the electrode and the reactant molecules. Finally, they need to be able to promote the intended reaction route and stable reactive intermediates, which calls for the right molecular architecture and coordination setting. Using metal complexes based on transition metals like cobalt, nickel, iron, and copper is one popular method for creating heterogeneous molecule electrocatalysts [30]. Because they can undergo reversible oxidation and reduction, these metals are desirable for electrocatalysis because they can take and supply electrons during catalytic reactions. In addition, they can fine-tune their electrical and structural characteristics by forming stable coordination complexes with a variety of ligands [24]. The selection of the support material is a crucial factor to consider when constructing heterogeneous molecular electrocatalysts. When it comes to stabilizing the metal complex and allowing electron transmission between the electrode and the metal complex, the support material is essential. Conducting polymers, carbon-based materials like carbon nanotubes, graphene, and activated carbon as well as metal oxides like indium tin oxide and titanium dioxide are examples of common support materials for its immobilization. Cobalt phthalocyanine complex is one illustration of a heterogeneous molecular electrocatalyst [31]. An essential stage in the creation of renewable chemicals and fuels, the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide, has been demonstrated to be highly successful at being catalyzed by this material. The reduction reaction can proceed with great efficiency and selectivity because the cobalt phthalocyanine complex is able to enable electron transport from the electrode to carbon dioxide. The iron porphyrin complex is another classical example of a heterogeneous molecular electrocatalyst [32]. It has been demonstrated that this substance is very good at accelerating the electrochemical oxidation of water to form oxygen, which is a crucial step in the creation of renewable hydrogen fuel. The iron porphyrin complex can aid electron transfer from the electrode to water, which contribute to the occurrence of the oxidation reaction with high efficiency and selectivity. Fig. 3 summarizes some examples of porphyrins structures used in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction studies over the years and various prototypes (Fe-porphyrins and Co-porphyrins) [23]. Researchers can tune the catalysts to boost chemical reactions while limiting undesirable side reactions by inventing and synthesizing particular compounds. Conventional solid-state catalysts frequently have a wide range of reactivity that is challenging to control, making it difficult to reach this level of control. We may anticipate seeing more of these materials used in a variety of industrial and technological applications as our knowledge of their characteristics and capabilities grows. 2 Realization of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts 2.1 Immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon The realization of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts is an exciting and rapidly growing field that has the potential to revolutionize various applications, such as energy conversion, environmental remediation, and chemical synthesis. The immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon has emerged as a promising approach for the development of highly efficient and stable electrocatalysts. Nanocarbon materials, such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene, have been widely used as substrates for the immobilization of molecular models due to their high surface area, excellent mechanical and chemical stability, and unique electronic properties. The immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon can be achieved through various methods, including covalent bonding, non-covalent interactions, and physical adsorption. Covalent bonding is a widely used method for the immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon. This approach involves the introduction of functional groups onto the nanocarbon surface, which can then react with the target molecule to form a covalent bond. For example, Marianov et al. [33] worked on the influence of covalent immobilization on the performance of Mn tetraphenylporphyrin in oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of a ruthenium complex onto the surface of CNTs through the reaction of carboxylic acid groups on the CNT surface with amine groups on the complex. This approach resulted in the formation of a stable and highly active electrocatalyst for the reduction of carbon dioxide. Non-covalent interactions, such as π-π stacking and electrostatic interactions, have also been utilized for the immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon. These methods offer several advantages, such as simplicity and reversibility. Amin et al. [34] reported the grafting of a series of zinc(II) complexes on the surface of graphene oxide (GO) via non-covalent interaction. This resulted in a stable Zn/GO material as an efficient electrocatalyst for hydrogen production. The application of density functional theory (DFT) simulations revealed a significant interaction between Zn and the supported material (GO) through non-covalent interactions, which confirms the catalytic activity of GO in facilitating Zn's hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process. Also, the results indicate that the HER activity of the catalyst increased with increasing catalyst loading density. Physical adsorption is another approach for the immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon. This method involves the physical adsorption of the target molecule onto the surface of nanocarbon through weak interactions such as van der Waals forces. Zhu et al. [35] synthesized Pd/CNTs with different palladium loadings. Pd was immobilized onto the surface of CNTs through physical adsorption as illustrated in Fig. 4 a. The resulting electrocatalyst exhibited excellent performance for the application in hydrogen evolution reaction (Fig. 4b-d). The immobilization of molecular models onto nanocarbon has a wide range of potential applications in electrocatalysis. The immobilization of metal complexes onto nanocarbon surfaces can enhance their stability and activity, making them useful for various applications such as the ORR, HER, and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR). Similarly, the immobilization of enzymes onto nanocarbon surfaces can enhance their catalytic activity, making them useful for various biotechnological applications such as biosensors and bioreactors. 2.2 Incorporation of molecular models with conductive materials The incorporation of molecular models with conduction materials is a promising approach for the development of efficient and stable heterogeneous electrocatalysts. The combination of molecular models and conduction materials can provide synergistic effects, leading to enhanced catalytic activity and stability. Conduction materials, such as metal oxides, metal sulfides, and conductive polymers, have been widely used as substrates for the incorporation of molecular models due to their high electrical conductivity, abundant active sites, and excellent stability. The incorporation of molecular models with conduction materials can be achieved through various methods, including electrodeposition and surface modification. Electrodeposition is an approach for the incorporation of molecular models with conduction materials. This method involves the co-deposition of the molecular model and the conduction material on a substrate through a deposition technique such as electrochemical deposition or chemical vapor deposition. For example, Zhan et al. [36] reported the electrodeposition of sulfur and CoxS on carbon nanotubes buckypaper as a binder-free high-performance cathode for lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery as shown in Fig. 5 a. The resulting S/CoxS/BP material recorded a high capacity which can be attributed to two factors: the homogenous dispersion of nanosized sulfur within the buckypaper and the presence of CoxS catalyst. Overall, the incorporation of molecular models with conduction materials such as buckypaper and CoxS catalyst can improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S battery. This conclusion is supported by experimental results reported in literature, which demonstrate the high capacity and improved cycling stability of S/CoxS/BP electrode (Fig. 5b-d). Surface modification is a more complex method for the incorporation of molecular models with conduction materials. In this method, the surface of the conducting material is changed by adding functional groups, and then the molecular model is covalently attached to the changed surface. For instance, Li et al. [37] fabricated a stable N-C@CNT-Fe electrocatalyst from high-conductivity CNTs wrapped by carbonized hemoglobin-derived Fe-N-C nanolayers, which is promising for four-electron ORR. The surface modification of CNT with hemoglobin leads to the formation of ORR active moieties such as Fe-N, pyridinic-N and graphitic-N which enhances the electrocatalytic activities. In another study, Alekseeva et al. [38] synthesized a nano-dispersed copper-impregnated platinum catalyst on a poly[Cu(Salen)] template. The catalyst recorded a high activity when used for ORR, surpassing that of both polycrystalline Pt catalyst and commercial carbon-platinum catalyst. The incorporation of molecular models with conduction materials has a wide range of potential applications in electrocatalysis. The incorporation of metal complexes with metal oxides or metal sulfides can enhance their stability and activity, making them useful for various applications. The choice of method depends on the specific application and the properties of the target molecule and conduction material. With the growing interest in the development of heterogeneous electrocatalysts, the exploration of new conduction materials and the optimization of incorporation methods are expected to continue in the coming years. 2.3 Self-Assembly of molecular models A potent method for precisely controlling the structure of complex materials at the molecular level is self-assembly. Recently, self-assembly has been used to make heterogeneous electrocatalysts that are more stable and work better for important electrochemical reactions like the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [39–41]. Self-assembly is the process by which molecules spontaneously arrange themselves into predetermined patterns by non-covalent interactions such as van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonds, and stacking of π-π [41,42]. This makes it possible to precisely regulate the shape, size, and makeup of the final products. It is feasible to produce electrocatalysts with specialized qualities that can outperform conventional catalysts by carefully choosing the molecular building blocks, and structure and perfecting the self-assembly conditions [43,44]. The use of block copolymers or surfactants as templates to drive the creation of specific structures is a popular method for electrocatalysts to self-assemble. Due to their distinctive geometries and surface characteristics, materials with certain shapes, such as nanotubes, nanowires, or nanoparticles, can display improved activity and stability. Self-assembly can be utilized not only to control the shape, but it is also possible to use it to modify the composition of the electrocatalyst by carefully inserting dopants or alloying components. Encouraging the creation of active sites or increasing the material's conductivity can further improve the electrocatalytic properties [45–47]. Self-assembly methods have been adopted to create and modify template-free single-atom catalysts (SAC) with Mn-N-C with numerous active sites for various electrocatalytic applications, as shown in Fig. 6 a [47]. Modified amidoxime can be prepared from transition metal ions as polymeric polyacrylonitrile (PAN) beads with tunable pore size and structure using facile self-assembly techniques (Fig. 6b) [48]. Acidic oxygen evolution processes are commonly benchmarked using iridium (Ir)-based electrocatalysts. The difficulties in identifying more active species and unfavorable designs make it difficult to further improve their catalytic activity. Zu et al. used a nanoconfined self-assembly method to create ultrathin nanosheets of Ir-IrOx/C with ordered interlayer spacing for improved OER. The synthesized Ir-IrOx/C nanosheets had well-controlled interlayer distances, and their distribution within the nanosheets was uniform, as shown in Fig. 6c [40]. Different molecular models have been used to make different types of heterogeneous electrocatalysts for the activation of dioxygen. Dioxygen activation is a crucial reaction in energy conversion and storage systems like fuel cells and metal-air batteries [49]. Metalloporphyrins are frequently used as building blocks in self-assembly of molecular models for the activation of dioxygen. It is well known that metalloporphyrins can bind dioxygen and make it easier for OER and ORR to be activated. It can be added to a self-assembled catalyst structure to produce a substance with increased activity and stability [50,51]. The use of porous templates like metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for self-assembly is an alternative strategy [52,53]. These porous materials are composed of metal ions and/or clusters that are joined by organic ligands. Organic compounds and metal ions with specific characteristics can be incorporated into MOFs since their pores have a large surface area. As a result, catalysts with improved activity and selectivity for the OER and ORR may be produced. The design of heterogeneous electrocatalysts for the activation of dioxygen is made possible through the self-assembly of molecular models. This opens the door to more effective and sustainable energy conversion technologies using self-assembled heterogeneous catalysts. 2.4 Covalent bonding assembly of molecular models An intriguing and practical method for building 3D models of molecules is covalent bonding assembly. Covalent bonds are used in the procedure to connect atoms in a specific configuration that corresponds to a particular molecule. The generated molecular model can then be used to better comprehend the molecule's structure, characteristics, and behavior. Covalent bonding in the construction of molecular models has a number of benefits, one of which is that it enables a practical method of learning chemistry. MOFs and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) were created by joining molecular building blocks with covalent bonds to form crystalline extended structures, expanding the accuracy and adaptability of covalent chemistry beyond discrete molecules. The main development in this area has been the creation of methods for overcoming the "crystallization difficulty," which is typically experienced when attempting to combine molecular building blocks into covalent solids [54]. By using the tip of an atomic force microscope to create such structures block by block on bilayer sodium chloride (NaCl) films on Cu(111) as shown in Fig. 7 a, Zhong et al. [55] demonstrated a flexible method for monitoring structural changes with single-bond precision. By sequentially de-halogenating, translating, and coupling halogenated precursors, covalent homo-dimers in cis and trans configurations as well as homo-/hetero-trimers were created. Complex bonding patterns like carbon-iodine-carbon bonds and fused carbon pentagons are more examples of structural build-up. Using interlayer and intralayer covalent bonding, Zhou et al. created ultrathin multilayer films with unique three-dimensional patterns using a two-dimensional production technique. Using bi- and multi-functional molecules as building blocks, the films were put together layer by layer on a silicon surface and reinforced by lateral cross-linking. The surface roughness after each layer was deposited within 0.2 nm, which allowed for sub-nanoscale control for the production process [56]. Punireddy and co-workers looked at how to create useful nanostructures in organic/polymeric matrices that had a definite chemical, thermal, and mechanical durability. Interests include molecule orientation, surface functionalization, layer-by-layer (LBL) assembly in diverse environments, including supercritical, the inclusion of functional moieties, and interfacial interactions. They showed the durability of ultrathin LBL molecular assemblies with inter-layer covalent linkages that incorporate polyimides and oligoimides [57]. Schultz et al. [58] investigated the coupling processes of tetra(4-bromophenyl)porphyrin (Br4TPP) molecules on an Ag(100) substrate that led to the development of 2D covalent networks using low temperature ultrahigh vacuum scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) as shown in Fig. 7b. The conformation of molecular precursors on the substrate was deciphered using a combination of STM topographic imaging and TERS vibrational fingerprinting. After the thermally stimulated coupling reaction, STM and TERS imaging supported the 2D networks' covalent structure and provided evidence that the apparent disorder is caused by molecular flexibility (Fig. 7c) [58]. 3 Molecular-based heterogeneous electrocatalysts for activation of dioxygen 3.1 Chemistry of electrocatalytic O2 activations For energy conversion, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is of primary importance, especially for fuel cells and metal air batteries [59]. Several mechanisms driving ORR have been proposed. However, the most accepted ORR mechanism proposed by Damjanovic and later modified by Wroblowa et al. elucidated the complex reaction pathway of oxygen on metal surfaces [60,61]. Following this, it was established that ORR proceeded along two pathways with comparable rates where either a 2-electron or 4-electron transfer occurred. To realize this, the use of molecular based electrocatalysts presents itself as an optimized alternative. However, most enzymes for H2 oxidation are poisoned by O2, a condition that remains a big challenge. Furthermore, the traces of CO that accompany H2 that are derived from water-gas shift reactions inhibit H2 oxidation catalyst. For O2 reduction, cytochrome c oxidase (CcO) and multicopper oxidase (MCO) are two enzymes known to cause the reduction in nature [64]. Currently, the complete reduction of O2 which requires the transfer of 4e− and 4H+ suggests further oxidation of the catalyst, which would involve higher oxidation states of the metal active sites and greatly affect the redox potential. Heterogeneous electrocatalysis of oxygen reduction reactions with molecular complexes requires their attachment to electrode surfaces. To achieve this, electrocatalysts such as porphyrinoid catalysts, metallocorrole catalysts, metallophalocyanine catalysts, and non-porphyrinic systems have been employed. The overpotential of oxygen reduction reactions mediated by porphyrinotoiron complexes can be lowered by the introduction of electron-withdrawn groups [65]. Recently, several methods have been employed to enhance ORR activity based on Pt. The exterior surfaces of One-Dimensional (1-D) nanostructures are known to possess smooth and low-energy facets on which oxygen binding energy is weak and thus results in higher ORRR [66]. For this reason, nanorods, nanowires, and nanotubes have been explored for such electrocatalytic reactions. However, nanowires are noted to be limited by their small surface area, whereas nanotubes offer a higher surface area since both their interior and exterior walls are available for reactions [67]. Core-shelled structure have been investigated as catalysts in attempts to improve the efficiency of Pt atoms by the deposition of thin Pt-based shell around inexpensive cores [68–70]. Chemical reduction approaches where Pt salts are reduced in organic or aqueous solvents and deposited on the cores have also been studied. Other techniques that have yielded results include Dealloying. Fig. 9 illustrates some schematics of various methods that have been employed to produce core-shelled structures. Metal based oxides, nitrides, oxynitrides, carbonitrides and chalcogenides have also been investigated as catalyst support to replace carbon owing to their chemical stability in acidic media [71]. Currently, the main drawbacks of metal oxides are their low electrical conductivity and insufficient adsorption sites. However, processes such as alloying, surface modification, and the formation of nanoparticles help address this drawback. 3.3 Oxygen evolution reaction Growing energy demands coupled with the urgency to protect the environment make the development of technologies such as regenerative fuel cells, metal-air batteries, CO2 reduction, and alkaline water electrolysis highly important for future industrialization [74]. The conventional two-electrode configuration of these technologies comprises a cathode part responsible for the evolution of hydrogen (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) proceeding on the anode side. One prevalent setback to the full-scale commercialization of these technologies is the unfavorable kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction at the anode side [63]. Oxygen evolution reaction is a four electron-proton coupled reaction that requires higher energy (higher overpotential) than hydrogen evolution reaction (two electron transfer), as shown in Fig. 10 . To address the sluggish reaction kinetics, electrocatalytic OER and, for that matter, catalysts synthesized from different material compositions and structures have been studied. OER catalysts based on noble metal oxides, metal oxides containing transition metals, metal oxide systems such as perovskite, spinels, and layer-structured materials (M(OH)2, MOOH, and LiMO2; M = Mn, Fe, Co and Ni) have been reported to exhibit impressive activity towards the oxygen evolution reaction [75–79]. Noble metal oxides, particularly rutile-type RuO2 and IrO2 are regarded as standard electrocatalysts for OER due to their high electrocatalytic activities towards OER in acidic and alkaline electrolytes. In spite of their excellent OER behavior, their high cost and instability in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes, leading to the oxidation and absorption of RuO4 and IrO3 compounds in solution, have inspired the development of other metal oxide families which offer facile synthesis, low cost and eco-friendly benefits [76,80]. Most importantly, metal oxides containing transition metals offer tunable OER behavior due to their different oxidation states and coordination environments [81,82]. Dissimilarly, non-oxide catalysts such as metal chalcogenides TC, TC2, T9S8, Ni3C2, T3S4 (T = Co and Ni, C = S, Se and Te), metal pnictides Co2N, Co3N, Co4N, Ni3N, TP and T2P, and organometallics have been reported as promising electrocatalysts for both HER, OER and overall water splitting [83–90]. Unlike their oxide counterparts, few cases of non-oxide electrocatalysts have been successfully documented. Metal chalcogenides are reported to exhibit excellent OER behavior with low overpotentials coupled with good stability in alkaline electrolyte. Metal pnictides on the other hand exhibit lower overpotential from HER and OER activities compared with other electrocatalysts and could be effective for overall water splitting [63]. Understanding the OER mechanism remains a crucial step in understanding material performance and subsequent innovation to meet these functionalities. Organometallics have limited practicality as OER electrocatalysts due to their low electrocatalytic activity. However, they are known to be suitable for in-depth studies of the OER mechanism due to their tunable molecular and electronic structures. To improve their electrocatalytic activities, a recent study immobilized organometallics on substrates such as graphene or reduced graphene oxide, which significantly improved their activities [91]. One breakthrough is the ability to monitor the OER via operando measurements, which provides more insight into specific intermediate phases and the electrochemical behavior on the surface of materials. The strong correlation between such in situ measurements, experimental Tafel analysis and theoretical data from density functional theory presents sufficient foreknowledge towards an overall understanding of the mechanism of OER. 4 Conclusion To sum up, this review focused on molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for dioxygen activation, which is a key process for energy storage and conversion. In the last few decades, the creation of novel heterogeneous electrocatalysts that can effectively activate dioxygen has created tremendous interest in the energy sector. A novel tactic for dioxygen activation has recently surfaced: the fabrication of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts. Designing heterogeneous electrocatalysts that mimic the architectural and functional characteristics of metalloenzymes, which are naturally occurring catalysts that effectively activate dioxygen, has been considered one way to accomplish this goal. To realize the molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for O2 activation, several strategies, including their immobilization onto solid substrates (metal oxides, nanocarbons, metal-organic frameworks, etc.), which offer the essential surface area, activity, and stability required for catalysis, and their assembly via covalently or non-covalently forming heterogeneous architectures, have been implemented, as documented in this review. The molecular heterogenous models for the O2 activations have proven their promising candidature as electrocatalysts for ORR and OER. For example, metal porphyrin and metal phthalocyanine-type molecular catalysts have been immobilized on carbon nanotubes and graphene surfaces, as well as MOFs, to achieve their ideal OER and ORR performance. Despite the molecular models' significant potential as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for dioxygen activation, there are still a number of issues that need to be resolved. Designing and synthesizing ligand-coordinated metal complexes that are stable, active, and functional in corrosive environments, especially at high pressure and temperatures and under electrocatalytic conditions, is a significant problem. The creation of techniques for highly effective and stable immobilization of these complexes onto solid substrates is therefore essential for their practical use as electrocatalysts. The creation of methods to increase the selectivity and effectiveness of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts is a further issue. Understanding the structure-function correlations of these complexes, the process of dioxygen activation, and the variables affecting catalytic activity and selectivity are all necessary for this. The creation of methods to increase the selectivity and effectiveness of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts is another issue. In this context, understanding structure-function correlations for these molecular models, dioxygen activation chemistry, and variables affecting catalytic selectivity and activity can resolve the above-mentioned issues with molecular catalysts. Moreover, according to the findings of the molecular models discussed in this review, chemical modification of the molecular catalysts (substitution on the molecular framework, axial ligation, metal exchange, use of conductive support) can be a good strategy to improve the catalytic performance further. These approaches can tailor the interaction between the active site of molecular catalysts and oxygen species during O2 catalysis. Therefore, a new generation of energy conversion and storage technologies will be made possible by the incorporation of molecular models into functioning devices like batteries and fuel cells. Also, new methods for describing the structure and characteristics of molecules, like X-ray spectroscopy and computer modeling, will shed light on the mechanism of dioxygen activation and the variables affecting the efficiency of catalysis. We expect that this review will help readers develop a firmer grasp of the underlying scientific and engineering principles necessary to design efficient molecular and atomically dispersed single- or multi-atom-based electrocatalysts for O2 activation. coredata.dc:description: Many chemical reactions and biological functions depend on the activation of dioxygen (O2). The development of effective and selective electrocatalysts for O2 activation, which is necessary for use in oxygen sensors, fuel cells, and other electrochemical devices, remains a difficulty despite the significance of this process. Due to their clearly defined structures, adaptable characteristics, and high catalytic activity, molecular models have recently become prominent contenders for electrocatalytic O2 activation. This review concentrates on the synthesis, modification, and performance evaluation of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for O2 activation. The benefits and drawbacks of several molecular model types, such as metalloporphyrins, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), and metalloenzymes as electrocatalysts for O2 activation, are examined in length. Due to their adjustable porosity, large surface area, and capacity to incorporate various metal ions, MOFs are a particularly interesting family of molecular models. Contrarily, metalloporphyrins are well known for their high preference and catalytic activity for O2 activation. The realization of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for O2 activation constitutes a viable path for the creation of efficient, durable, and selective electrochemical devices.
coredata.dc:title: Realization of molecular models as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for activation of dioxygen
